chunks.cleaned_english_translation: I saw a book in the right hand of God, who was sitting on the throne. It was written inside and outside and sealed with seven seals. In the right hand, in Christ, he says, for he is the arm of God, the right hand of the Father, or in supreme happiness. The book written inside and outside represents both Testaments. The outside refers to the Old Testament, which was seen; the inside refers to the New Testament, which was hidden within the Old. Hence, the Apostle addresses the Hebrews, saying, Hebrews 12: "For you have not come to what can be touched, a blazing fire, darkness, gloom, a tempest, the sound of a trumpet, and a voice whose words made the hearers beg that no further messages be spoken to them; for they could not endure the order that was given." Now, comparing spiritual things with spiritual, we do not look at what is seen, but at what is not seen. For what is seen is temporary, but what is not seen is eternal. Therefore, it is called one book because neither the New Testament without the Old, nor the Old without the New, is complete. The Old Testament is the herald and veil of the New, and the New is the fulfillment and revelation of the Old. Although the Old was outside, it did not all appear; it was not all hidden. To express it more clearly, all the dispensation of the Savior under the name of the book is often read, whether promised or completed in both Testaments. Sealed with seven seals, it is covered with the multifaceted fullness of hidden mysteries, hence also from the shadowy and dense mountain. Although the number seven embraces universality, I think that seven modes, like seven signs in the divine Scriptures, should be openly sought in exercises and necessarily found. Not only of the sayings, which even worldly authors, by God's revelation, could regularly observe in their writings, but also of saving understanding, which is said to have remained reserved specially for Christ to reveal. For as long as the same Lord turned water into wine in those six jars, as in six ages, understanding the Old Testament spiritually, the law could not intoxicate anyone with the fervor of the spirit.

Those signs had remained closed until now. After carefully examining the sacred pages, we can see that speech can be understood in seven ways: indicative, declarative, imperative, optative, conjunctive, infinitive, and impersonal.

For example, the indicative is found in Micah 6:

"I will show you, man, what is good, and what the Lord requires of you: to love justice, to show mercy, and to walk humbly with your God."

And in Isaiah 48:

"I am the Lord your God, who teaches you what is good, who leads you in the way you should go."

Also, when asked in Isaiah 63:

"Who is this coming from Edom, with dyed garments from Bozrah?"

it is answered indicatively:

"I who speak righteousness, mighty to save."

Declarative:

"Listen to me, Jacob, and Israel, whom I called; I am the first, and I am the last, and besides me, there is no God" (Isaiah 48).

Also in Isaiah 40:

"Why do you say, Jacob, and speak, Israel: 'My way is hidden from the Lord, and my judgment is passed over by my God'? Do you not know, have you not heard: the everlasting God, the Lord, the Creator of the ends of the earth, does not faint or grow weary; his understanding is unsearchable. He gives strength to the weary."

And in Jeremiah 21:

"Behold, the days are coming, says the Lord, when I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and the house of Judah."

Imperative:

"You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain"; and, "You shall have no other gods before me" (Exodus 20).

And in Isaiah 58:

"Cry aloud, do not hold back, lift up your voice like a trumpet."

Optative:

"Oh, that you had paid attention to my commandments! Then your peace would have been like a river, and your righteousness like the waves of the sea" (Isaiah 48);

And in Psalm 119:

"Oh that my ways may be steadfast in keeping your statutes!"

And in Psalm 55:

"Oh, that I had wings like a dove! I would fly away and be at rest."

Conjunctive:

"If you listen to my voice and keep my covenant, you will be my treasured possession among all peoples; for all the earth is mine, and you will be to me a kingdom of priests and a holy nation" (Exodus 19).

Elsewhere also: "I will dwell in them and walk among them, and I will be their God, and they shall be My people" Leviticus 26.

Or, "If they had stood in My counsel, surely I would have turned them from their evil thoughts" Jeremiah 23.

Furthermore, the infinitive mood, which is also the sixth in order: "To know and understand the Lord, and to do judgment and justice in the midst of the earth" Jeremiah 9.

Likewise, "To refrain from evil, is understanding" Micah 6.

Impersonal, "Who has helped the Spirit of the Lord? With whom did He take counsel, and who instructed Him, and taught Him the path of justice, and showed Him the way of prudence" Job 28?

Or in what is written: "Who among you will give ear to this, pay attention and listen for the future" Isaiah 40?

And, "Who is the man who fears the Lord? He will instruct him in the way he should choose" Psalm 25?

Or, "To understand the law is the best sense; and, Who can speak of the mighty acts of the Lord" Psalm 105?

And other similar things, which can be more suitably applied to each of the modes. These, I say, we easily find in words; but now, just order demands that we fit the regular forms of intelligence to the very things themselves as by seven signs with suitable testimonies, or rather that we prove the testimonies themselves to serve the same rules.

For although the previously mentioned modes of speech seem somewhat appropriate, they are deemed insufficient for what we are seeking. Therefore, the book is said to be sealed with seven seals, because a higher secret mode, which had previously been hidden there but is asserted to have been revealed by the dispensation of Christ, should be pointed out.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
For those of us studying the Scriptures, the first layer we encounter is the historical narrative, followed by the allegorical meaning. The third layer recognizes both aspects, while the fourth concerns the unchanging essence of the Divine Trinity, whether it is properly or figuratively suggested in the sacred texts. The fifth layer relates to parables, crafted through narrative and action, so that when something is said or written, it may hold a different meaning, uplifting the mind to spiritual understanding.

The sixth layer pertains to the dual advent of the Savior, or matters related to it, ensuring that the first is not confused with the second, and vice versa. A great deal of discernment is required here. This is why the minds of the Jews were clouded when the Lord came, and they still suffer from the same blindness. Sometimes prophecy concerning human sins and transgressions foretells future deeds or the hidden senses of spiritual matters.

The seventh layer instructs us with divine precepts, establishing a clear form of living and making a symbolic representation of living known. We must carefully consider what is written externally and what is internal.

Now, it is fitting to teach these layers with examples. The historical layer, which is the first, tells us in this way that there is one God: Hear, O Israel, the Lord your God is one Lord (Deuteronomy 6:4), and that everything was made by Him, and similar things.

The second allegorical layer is like this: Abraham obtains an oath from his servant in a new and unusual manner, saying: Put your hand under my thigh and swear by the Lord, the God of heaven (Genesis 24:2-3). This is recognized as symbolic because it is not a common practice generally, except for Abraham and Jacob, the special prophetic patriarchs, from whose lineage Christ was expected to be born physically.

For instance, from all the faithful in Israel, a girl is sought for King David and found to be so fervent that she could warm the old king's cold limbs with suitable heat (First Kings 1:1-4).

The sixth way to recognize the advent of Christ is by discerning what pertains to his first coming and what pertains to his second coming.

The first coming is associated with places of humility, as Moses says in Deuteronomy 18: "The Lord your God will raise up for you a prophet like me from among your brothers; you shall listen to him."

Also, "Afterward, you appeared on earth and lived among men" (Baruch). And again, "He had no beauty or majesty to attract us to him, nothing in his appearance that we should desire him. He was despised and rejected by mankind, a man of suffering" (Isaiah 53).

And a little later, "Surely he took up our pain" (same book). And again, "He was led like a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before its shearers is silent, so he did not open his mouth" (same book).

About the second coming, we read: "Our God will come and will not be silent" (Psalm 50). And, "They will look on the one they have pierced" (Zechariah 12).

Malachi also says: "I will come to put you on trial. I will be quick to testify against sorcerers, adulterers, and perjurers, against those who defraud laborers of their wages" (Malachi 3), etc.

What we have said about the sins of certain men often symbolizes something prophetic, where signs of inner and outer indications seem to shine forth.

The public sin of David in Second Samuel 11 and 12 concerning the wife of Uriah the Hittite was evident, but the prophecy from his evil deed figured something good for us.

Bathsheba indeed means "well of satisfaction" or "seventh well," which specifically signifies the Church. Christ, having separated her and killed the devil, to whose illegitimate company she was bound, joined her to himself from the nations.

We also read about this in the Song of Songs (Song of Solomon 4): "A well of living water"; this number is joined because of the sevenfold operation of the Holy Spirit.

For even in the name of Uriah the Hittite, the person of the devil is clearly signified.

<speak>
    Uriah, whose name means "My light is of God," was a Hittite, which means "cut off." This could be because he did not stand in truth and was cut off from his heavenly light due to his pride or because, having lost his true strength by falling, he transforms himself as an angel of light Second Corinthians 11, still daring to say: "My light is of God." 

    <break time="1s"/>

    King David, a strong man, saw a woman bathing on the roof of her house. With a lustful eye, he desired her and took her Second Samuel 11. Christ, the King of kings, saw the Church, cleansed by washing and the word, treading on earthly things, longing for heavenly things, and predestined her. The provident groom loved her when she was called, so that he might join her, justified, to himself in a legitimate spiritual marriage, just as Moses Exodus 2 in the person of Christ was taken from the water, struck down the Egyptian who was plotting against the Hebrew, that is, the devil hostile to the Israelites, with a blow of his foot, and covered the slain under the sand. 

    For all of you, says the Apostle Galatians 3, who were baptized into Christ have clothed yourselves with Christ. In Him, we will do mighty deeds, so that we can confidently say: "I will extend my shoe over Edom; foreigners are subject to me" Psalm 60. He who crushes Satan under our feet allows his corpse to lie in those whom he recognizes as unstable, truly comparing them to the shifting sand. 

    We also know this happened to Tamar, Judah's daughter-in-law Genesis 38, and many others, so that when they fell into sin, God, who knows how to use even our evils well, might enact another mystery through them. 

    For the Apostle teaches First Corinthians 10 that all things that happened to that people at that time were prophecies of things to come. And although they might have paid the purgatorial penalties for their sins or obtained pardon through the remedies of repentance, divine mercy has prepared the effect of Christ's dispensation for us. Therefore, sins appeared outwardly, but mysteries were hidden within. 

    For this reason, I preferred to pass over the story of Judah's daughter-in-law, so that I might not extend this work with much more lengthy discourse.</speak>

The seven stages of inner human renewal, through the grace of God's Spirit of the mind, observed by our fathers. Blessed Augustine speaks of these in the book On True Religion as follows:

The first stage is in the nurturing breasts of useful history, which nourishes with examples. According to Jacob, forgetting the human and aspiring to the divine, it is not contained by human authority but relies on the highest and unchangeable law through steps of reason.

The third stage, already more confident and uniting the carnal appetite with the strength of reason, rejoices inwardly in a certain marital sweetness. When the soul is united with the mind and is veiled by modesty, it is no longer compelled to live rightly: even if all permit, it is not allowed to sin.

The fourth stage, already doing much more firmly and orderly by that very fact, shines forth into a perfect man, and is apt and suitable for enduring and breaking all persecutions and the storms and waves of the world.

The fifth stage, living peacefully and entirely tranquil in every respect, experiences the abundance of the unchangeable kingdom of the highest and ineffable wisdom.

The sixth stage, in every way transforming into eternal life, passes into the complete forgetting of temporal life, in the perfect form that was made in the image and likeness of God.

The seventh stage is eternal rest and undistinguished by any ages, perpetual blessedness. For as the end of the old man is death, so the end of the new man is eternal life. He had previously and justly threatened, saying through Hosea in Hosea 13: I will be your death, O death; I will be your sting, O hell. And Isaiah in Isaiah 11: Behold, the root of Jesse will stand as a banner for the peoples; the nations will seek him, and his resting place will be glorious. For each believer, when we strive to weep for our sins and remember the promised redemption through the consolation of the Scriptures, we know we have eternal salvation, affirmed by a response similar to one of the elders. Therefore, he promised both past and future, because the Spirit subtly refers to the past and demonstrates the future as described in Romans 15. And I saw, and behold, in the midst of the throne and the four living creatures and in the midst of the elders, The throne, the living creatures, and the elders represent the Church. In the midst of the Church, a lamb standing as though it had been slain. For as often as Christ, having been slain, is preached in the midst of the Church, the same Lamb is seen as if sacrificed for the sins of the world. These things, unknown to the unlearned, are revealed, and the Son is sculpted in the memory of a devoted worshipper. When the Church, which Christ clothes, mortifies itself to the world to live to God, the Lamb is said to be sacrificed for the body, the head. chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
The variety of expressions has taught us to present one understanding, signifying the most excellent gifts of the Holy Spirit with horns, through which Christ reigns in His Church across the world.

It continues, "Who are the seven spirits of God." For nothing justly rules throughout the earth and is especially enlarged by the gift of the Holy Spirit except the Church of Christ.

Remember, the number seven is often used to represent the whole. But because the horns are above the head, the unique exaltation of the Church over Christ is rightly placed. Hence, "On this rock," He says, "I will build my Church" (Matthew 16), as if to say, "I will build you upon me" (Wisdom 1).

Moreover, "The Spirit of the Lord has filled the world" (Psalm 74). To make this happen, the horns of sinners are broken, and the horns of the righteous are said to be exalted. About this, Isaiah had predicted (Isaiah 24): "We have heard songs of praise from the ends of the earth declaring the glory of the righteous."

Therefore, having seven horns is understood to mean possessing the whole world, in which the sevenfold grace of the Spirit rules, due to His notable sevenfold operation, which He mentions here for the enlightenment of the eyes, about which I think Zechariah has said (Zechariah 4): "These seven are the eyes of the Lord, which roam throughout the earth."

But also the dignity of His excellence is fittingly expressed by the horns. For natural horns grow as if by breaking the confines of the place, not content with the level of the flesh, but seeking higher and higher as they grow. For the spiritual person judges all things, but is judged by no one (First Corinthians 2). Nor could anyone judge, unless, no longer being carnal in the body, they are elevated to a superior watchtower, presiding over others. Thus, the Apostle (Romans 8): "You," he says, "are not in the flesh, but in the spirit."

And He came and took the book from the right hand of God who was seated on the throne. The book from the right hand of God is said to be the dispensation arranged by the Father and Himself, which the Son of Man received, because both dwell with their spirit on the throne.

We should understand the right hand here as a symbol of blessed victory. It shouldn't be interpreted literally, as if the Son is receiving a book from the Father's right hand, since the Son himself is the right hand of the Father. As he always triumphs in his own, who says John 16: "Rejoice, because I have overcome the world," and has made his Church victorious, it is declared that he receives the book about this.

And when he had taken the book, the four living creatures and the twenty-four elders fell down before the Lamb, each having golden harps and golden bowls full of incense, which are the prayers of the saints. The living creatures and the elders, representing the whole Church, fall before the Lamb, not without acknowledging the virtues performed. Therefore, each having golden harps and golden bowls, with strings stretched over wood, represents the passion of Christ, which the Church continually imitates to fulfill what is lacking in the sufferings of Christ in their flesh, according to the Apostle Colossians 1.

The bowls symbolize a pious confession accepted by God, where nothing is hidden with a double heart, but is openly revealed by action. These are also the golden vessels in the great house Second Timothy 2, exuding the sweet fragrance of the good odor of Christ. Moreover, the prayers of the saints are thanksgivings from those celebrating the salvation of the world, and intercessions for the stability of the little ones.

Christ, he says, suffered for us, leaving us an example that we should follow in his steps First Peter 2. Therefore, when those who are Christ's crucify their flesh with its passions and desires Galatians 5, they play harps to Christ, so that as he did for them, they do for him, looking to Jesus, the author and finisher of their faith Hebrews 12.

When he wished to reveal himself with seven notable titles, he is shown to have performed seven secret signs: teaching that he is co-eternal with the Father as God, was born of a virgin, lived as a man, suffered, rose again, ascended into heaven, sent the Holy Spirit, acquired the Church from the Gentiles, and announced himself as the future judge.

chunks.cleaned_english_translation:
Let's hear what Isaiah says to the Jews: Isaiah 29, according to the Septuagint:

All these words will be to you like the words of a sealed book. Both the learned and the unlearned are deprived of understanding. The learned are prevented by the seals from accessing the inner secrets, and the unlearned are hindered by ignorance. The Lord rebukes the leaders of the Jews for taking away this key of knowledge, as stated in Matthew chapter 23: Woe to you, teachers of the law, who have taken away the key of knowledge; you yourselves have not entered, and you hinder those who are entering. By denying Christ, whose coming is prophesied, they were taking away the key of knowledge. Indeed, denying the faith blocks the knowledge of the law that contains Christ.

And singing a new song.

Christ brings forth a new song in harmony with the truth of both Testaments. Remaining the same Word from the beginning, He was born anew through a virgin, clothed as a man-God, handed over to death by His own authority, miraculously raised from the dead, elevated to the heavens, acquiring the nations with the Holy Spirit, and leaving a new song for the Church to continually sing. With this new song, the Church confidently hopes for the coming Judge, so that we may walk in newness of life, as stated in Romans chapter 6: If anyone wants to be my disciple, let him deny himself, take up his cross, and follow me, as it says in Luke chapter 9. You are worthy, Lord, to take the book and to open its seals, for you were slain, and with your blood you redeemed us for God, from every tribe and language and people and nation. You made us a kingdom and priests to our God, and we reigned on earth. They praise this very dispensation of Christ, designated by the name of the book, which they confess belongs to Christ alone. It is further declared that the creatures and elders represent the Church when they say: You redeemed us with your blood. For it is only fitting for the Church to say this.

And I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven. Matthew sixteen

He then moves on to the head, saying: And every creature that is in heaven and on earth and under the earth, and in the sea, and everything in them. It should not be difficult to accept that the Church received this with Him, with whom it rose again, just as a member has a head. Nor is it unjust to say the Church is worthy of every creature. Although each member judges itself unworthy with religious humility, we say the whole body shares in its head, of which we read: He gave us everything with Him. Likewise, He made us sit in the heavenly places.

We often know that "creature" signifies men, as the Apostle says: For the creation itself will be liberated from the bondage of corruption into the freedom of the glory of the children of God. Romans eight

And the Lord: Preach the Gospel to every creature. Mark sixteen For everything that pertains to all creatures is found in man: to be, to live, to move, to feel, to understand. Therefore, here he refers to every creature as every human being, that is, the whole world. Hence, he himself says: All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Matthew twenty-eight

He did not receive his authority in time, but wanted to signify the dignity of the Church in men. He, who teaches that he is equal to the Father in all things, so that what he says, who is in heaven, the very human nature in Christ is preferred to the angels, should rule in heaven: preached to men, reigning should rule on earth: who, prevailing, is taught to have ruled and under the earth, with the groans of the underworld loosened. I heard all saying: To him who sits on the throne and to the Lamb, that is, to the Father and the Son, blessing and honor and glory and power forever and ever. And the four living creatures said: Amen. The Church indeed says: Amen, that is, truly, faithfully. And the twenty-four elders fell on their faces and worshipped the living one forever and ever. The same living creatures are the elders, who bore witness, saying: Amen.

The Church was described, along with its duties and commendable works. It was essential to proceed in this manner so that, by revealing each of the signs, their meanings would become clear.

Indeed, nothing could be omitted from these seven signs. In their mystery, through affection, understanding, and action, all forms of perfection were shown to be present.

He describes, at times, starting from the end and going back to the beginning. He discusses both Christ's triumph and the future challenges the Church will face, reviewing the contents of each sign in his unique way. This approach provides both consolation from the victory's prosperity and concern for the upcoming battles, ultimately announcing the remarkable judgment.
